revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox golfer | name = Horace Hutchinson | image = HoraceHutchinson1889.JPG | imagesize = 190 | caption = Hutchinson in 1889
(Photo courtesy [[National Portrait Gallery, London]]) | fullname = Horatio Gordon Hutchinson | nickname = Horace | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1859|5|16}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1932|7|27|1859|5|16}} | death_place = [[Chelsea, London]], England | height = 5 ft 11.5 in | weight = {{convert|175|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | nationality = {{ENG}} | residence = | spouse = Dorothy Margaret Chapman | partner = | children = | college = [[Corpus Christi College, Oxford|Corpus Christi College]]
[[Oxford University]] | status = Amateur | yearpro = | retired = | tour = | extour = | prowins = | majorwins = | masters = DNP | usopen = DNP | open = 6th: [[1890 Open Championship|1890]] | pga = DNP | britamateur = '''Won''': 1886; 1887 | wghofid = | wghofyear = | award1 = | year1 = | awardssection = }} '''Horatio Gordon "Horace" Hutchinson''' (16 May 1859 – 27 July 1932){{cite news |newspaper=The Times |date=29 July 1932 |page=14 |title=Mr H G Hutchinson}}{{cite web |title=Mr. Horace Hutchinson |url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/20th-august-1932/14/mr-horace-hutchinson |accessdate=18 April 2015}} was an English amateur golfer who played in the late 19th century and early 20th century. Hutchinson won the [[The Amateur Championship|1886 Amateur Championship]] and the [[The Amateur Championship|1887 Amateur Championship]]. He had three top-10 finishes in the [[The Open Championship|Open Championship]], his best result being sixth in the [[1890 Open Championship]].{{cite book |title=The Majors of Golf: Complete Results of the Open, the U.S. Open, the PGA Championship and the Masters, 1860–2008 |volume=1 |first=Morgan G. |last=Brenner |year=2009 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-7864-3360-5}} He was also a prolific writer of books on the subject of golf and other sporting themes.{{cite web |title=Oxford Index – Horace G. Hutchinson (1859–1932), golfer and writer |url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095951960 |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=18 April 2015}} Hutchinson was the first English captain of the [[R&A]] links at [[St Andrews Golf Club]], Scotland. He suffered from grave illness in the latter portion of his life and committed suicide in [[Chelsea, London]], [[England]], on 27 July 1932. ==Early life== Hutchinson, born 16 May 1859 in [[London]], England, was the third son of General [[William Nelson Hutchinson]] (1803–1895). He began his golfing career at an early age playing at the [[Royal North Devon]] golf club—also known as [[Westward Ho!]]—a course founded in 1864 and designed by [[Old Tom Morris]].[http://www.golfcoursearchitecture.net/Article/Old-Tom-Morris/1423/Default.aspx Old Tom Morris] ''Golf Course Architecture'', 1 July 2006, accessed 30 January 2012. By the age of sixteen he won the club medal championship. He attended [[Corpus Christi College (Oxford)|Corpus Christi College]] for a time where he was a [[cricket]] player,{{cite web|title=Horatio Gordon Hutchinson|url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/352/352956/352956.html|website=cricketarchive.com|accessdate=20 April 2015}} then [[Oxford University]] from 1878–81{{cite news |title=Players of Golf |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1895-05-04/ed-1/seq-13/#date1=1886&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=Horace+Hutchinson&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=2&state=&date2=1903&proxtext=Horace+Hutchinson&y=14&x=21&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=6 |newspaper=The Evening Star |location=Washington, D.C. |date=4 May 1895 |page=13 |accessdate=16 April 2015}} where he made an immediate impression by playing number one on the Oxford golf team and led them to victory over arch rival [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] in the [[University Golf Match]]. [[Image:Horace Gordon Hutchinson, Vanity Fair, 1890-07-19.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Caricature by [[Leslie Ward|Spy]] of Hutchinson (1890), from ''[[Vanity Fair Caricatures|Vanity Fair]]'' magazine]] During his Oxford years he would spend vacations at home playing the Royal North Devon course accompanied by a young orphaned caddy who was employed by the Hutchinson family as a [[houseboy]]. The young lad went by the name of [[John Henry Taylor]]. Taylor's future exploits in golf—which included winning five Open Championships—would become legendary.{{cite web|last1=Stevens|first1=Mike|title=The Father of Golf Instruction|url=https://usgtf.com/articles/father.html|website=usgtf.com|accessdate=16 April 2015}} Hutchinson was a keen [[billiards]] player and enjoyed [[rowing]], shooting and [[angling]]. He graduated Oxford BA with third-class honours in ''[[literae humaniores]]'' (1881) and entered the [[Inner Temple]] with a view to reading for the bar, but his health, always frail, temporarily broke down.{{cite web|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biographies – Horatio Gordon Hutchinson|website=odnb2.ifactory.com|accessdate=20 April 2015}} In 1890 he considered becoming a sculptor and studied briefly under [[George Frederic Watts|G. F. Watts]]. In 1893 he married Dorothy Margaret Chapman, daughter of Major Frederick Barclay Chapman of the [[14th Hussars]].{{cite journal|author1=William, Arthur |author2=Pollock, Alsager |title=The Army Gazette, War Office, Pall Mall|journal=The United Service Magazine|date=1870|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=goVNAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA150&lpg=PA150&dq=frederick+barclay+chapman&source=bl&ots=sHd4wwWzfU&sig=9bxZQywLVk-6Dr3KPrL5xL4orDE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Ci81VZ-fHpbhoASd_YHgBQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=frederick%20barclay%20chapman&f=false|accessdate=20 April 2015}} ==The Amateur Championship== Hutchinson's major accomplishments in golf were his two victories in the 1886 and 1887 Amateur Championships. He became the first player to successfully defend the title by defeating the great [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]] on Ball's home course at [[Royal Liverpool Golf Club]] in [[Hoylake]]. Hutchinson was an avid student—and later teacher—of the mechanics of the golf swing, so he decided to put forth in writing his suggestions on methods of play. He said, among other things, "The great secret of all strokes played for the most part is to make the club travel as long as possible in the direction in which you want the ball to go". In 1896, showing his humorous side on the subject of golf etiquette, Hutchinson remarked: {{Quote|text=If your adversary is badly bunkered, there is no rule against your standing over him counting his strokes aloud, with increasing gusto as their number mounts up, but it will be a wise precaution to arm yourself with the niblick before doing so, so as to meet him on equal terms.{{cite web |title=Hole 4 – Golf Etiquette |url=http://www.thegolfballfactory.com/the-golf-course/hole4/Golf-course-etiquette.htm |accessdate=18 April 2015}}|author=Horace Hutchinson}} ==Business ventures== From 1910 a local director to their West End branch and later its chairmanRoyal Exchange Assurance. ''The Times'', Thursday, Apr 27, 1933; pg. 21; Issue 46429 Hutchinson was elected to the court of Directors of [[Royal Exchange Assurance Corporation]] in May 1919.City News in Brief. ''The Times'', Friday, May 09, 1919; pg. 19; Issue 42095 Following Hutchinson's death in 1932 the chairman of Royal Exchange began his address to their 213th Annual General Court by telling of his deepest regret. "He had the interests of the Corporation always very much at heart and the charm of his personality endeared him to his colleagues and to all those with whom he came in contact. He is very much missed by us all". In 1905, with his golfing friend H.C.B. Underdown, he became one of the two first directors of [[Commer|Commercial Cars Limited]] (Commer) which the pair of them set up to make Commer commercial vehicles. Their venture was intended to capitalize on a promising preselector gearbox invented for heavy vehicles. He remained on that board until his death. ==Death== Although he lived to be 73 years old, Hutchinson suffered with poor health most of his life, and was for the last eighteen years of life incapacitated by grave illness. Before 1920 he left his Sussex home, Shepherds Gate, Coleman's Hatch across Royal Ashdown Forest Golf Club from [[Forest Row]] and moved to 29 Lennox Gardens, Chelsea, London. Eighteen years after he could no longer play golf he committed suicide there on 27 July 1932. He was survived by his wife. According to his 1932 [[probate]], his wealth at death was [[£]]26,337 (£{{Formatprice|{{Inflation|GBP|26337|1932}}}} today).{{Inflation-fn|US}} ==Legacy== American golf teaching professional Mike Stevens said of Hutchinson, "In my mind, there is no question that Horace Hutchinson was a teacher extraordinaire and is clearly the father of golf instruction". [[Walter Travis]], in 1904—shortly after his victories in the 1903 U.S. Amateur and 1904 British Amateur—said of Hutchinson: {{Quote|text=All things considered, the golfer whom I most admired as a player was Horace Hutchinson. Over here we have read so many of his books and spoken of him so long as a veteran that one is surprised to find he is only forty-seven years old. He plays every shot for what it is worth and in perfect style, as free as any supple youth, and, all told, I pronounce him, to my mind, the ideal golfer.{{cite news |title=Views of Travis – Says Hutchinson, the Noted Britisher, Is an Ideal Golfer |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn92053934/1904-07-30/ed-1/seq-9/#date1=1836&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=Horace+Hutchinson&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=8&state=&date2=1922&proxtext=Horace+Hutchinson&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=5 |newspaper=Rock Island Argus |date=30 July 1904 |accessdate=16 April 2015}}|author=Walter Travis}} ==Tournament wins (25)== :''Note: This list may be incomplete.'' *1875 Royal North Devon Golf Club Boy's Bronze Scratch Medal,{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 29-34|year=1919}} Royal North Devon Golf Club Autumn Scratch Medal{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 41-46|year=1919}} *1878 Crookham Cup{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 47-52|year=1919}} *1879 Crookham Cup, Royal Liverpool Autumn Kennard Gold Medal,{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 59-64|year=1919}} Royal Liverpool Autumn Dowie Silver Cup Medal[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 179. *1880 Crookham Cup{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 47-52.|year=1919}} *1884 St. Andrews Autumn Gold Medal,{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 71-76|year=1919}} St. Andrews George Glennie Medal[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 211. *1885 Royal Liverpool Spring Connaught Challenge Star Medal[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 178. *1886 [[The Amateur Championship]], Royal North Devon Golf Club Spring Prince of Wales Gold Challenge Medal[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 218. *1887 [[The Amateur Championship]], St. Andrews Autumn Gold Medal,[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 206. St. Andrews Spring Silver Cross Medal, Great Yarmouth Scratch Medal,[https://books.google.com/books?id=li0PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1887-88''], edited by C. Robertson Bauchope, London 1888, Horace Cox publishers, p. 221. Royal North Devon Golf Club Spring Prince of Wales Gold Challenge Medal *1889 Royal Eastbourne Fall Hartington Gold Medal,[https://books.google.com/books?id=Bi4PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1889-90''], edited by David Scott Duncan, London 1890, Horace Cox publishers, p. 155. St. Andrews Autumn Gold Medal[https://books.google.com/books?id=Bi4PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1889-90''], edited by David Scott Duncan, London 1890, Horace Cox publishers, p. 243. *1892 Royal Eastbourne Spring Club Gold Medal,[https://books.google.com/books?id=lC4PAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Golfing Annual, 1892-93''], edited by David Scott Duncan, London 1893, Horace Cox publishers, p. 170. Royal Eastbourne Fall Hartington Gold Medal *1894 Royal Liverpool Spring Medal,{{cite book |title=Fifty Years of Golf |first=Horace |last=Hutchinson |authorlink=Horace Hutchinson |publisher=[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]], p. 150-155|year=1919}} Royal Liverpool Fall Medal *1895 Royal Liverpool Fall Medal *1896 Royal Liverpool Fall Medal ==Major championships== ===Amateur wins (2)=== {|class="wikitable" !Year!!Championship!!Winning Score!!Runner-up |- | 1886 || [[The Amateur Championship]] || align=center|7 & 6 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Henry Lamb (golfer)|Henry Lamb]] |- | 1887 || [[The Amateur Championship]] || align=center|1 up || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]] |- |} ===Results timeline=== Note: Hutchinson played in only [[The Open Championship]] and [[The Amateur Championship]]. {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: #aaa solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align:center;" |- style="background:#eeeeee;" ! style="text-align:left;" | Tournament !1885 !1886 !1887 !1888 !1889 |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Open Championship]] | T11 LA | T16 | style="background:yellow;"|T10 | DNP | DNP |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Amateur Championship]] | style="background:yellow;"|2 | style="background:lime;"|'''1''' | style="background:lime;"|'''1''' | style="background:yellow;"|R16 | R32 |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: #aaa solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align:center;" |- style="background:#eeeeee;" ! style="text-align:left;" | Tournament !1890 !1891 !1892 !1893 !1894 !1895 !1896 !1897 !1898 !1899 |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Open Championship]] | style="background:yellow;"|6 | T24 | style="background:yellow;"|10 | DNP | WD | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | CUT |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Amateur Championship]] | style="background:yellow;"|QF | DNP | style="background:yellow;"|QF | DNP | R32 | DNP | style="background:yellow;"|SF | DNP | style="background:yellow;"|R16 | DNP |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: #aaa solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align:center;" |- bgcolor="#eeeeee" ! style="text-align:left;" | Tournament !1900 !1901 !1902 !1903 !1904 !1905 !1906 !1907 !1908 !1909 |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Open Championship]] | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP | DNP |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Amateur Championship]] | R64 | style="background:yellow;"|SF | R64 | style="background:yellow;"|2 | style="background:yellow;"|SF | R128 | style="background:yellow;"|R16 | R64 | R256 | R64 |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: #aaa solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align:center;" |- style="background:#eeeeee;" ! style="text-align:left;" |Tournament !1910 !1911 !1912 |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Open Championship]] | DNP | DNP | DNP |- | style="text-align:left;" | [[The Amateur Championship]] | R32 | R64 | R256 |} LA = Low Amateur
NYF = Tournament not yet founded
NT = No tournament
DNP = Did not play
WD = Withdrew
"T" indicates a tie for a place
DNQ = Did not qualify for match play portion
R256, R128, R64, R32, R16, QF, SF = Round in which player lost in match play
Green background for wins. [http://la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/AmericanGolfer/1912/ag83d.pdf The American Golfer, July, 1912, pg. 197.] {{div col end}} ==Books written by Hutchinson== :''Note: This list may be incomplete.'' * ''Hints on the Game of Golf'' (1886) * ''The [[Badminton Library]] of Sports and Pastimes – Golf'' (1890)[http://www.library.uiuc.edu/rbx/exhibitions/Victorian%20Entertainments/catalog/catalog.html Victorian Entertainments: We Are Amused An Exhibit Illustrating Victorian Entertainment] at the Rare Book & Manuscript Library of the [[University of Illinois]] (Item 31: Golf in 1890, Item 32: Skating in 1892, Item 33: Cricket in 1888, Item 34: Cycling in 1887) online at library.uiuc.edu. Retrieved 18 April 2015 * ''The Golf Pilgrim on Many Links'' (1897){{cite web|title=Hutchinson, Horatio Gordon ('Horace'). The Golfing Pilgrim on Many Links|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/books-manuscripts/hutchinson-horatio-gordon-the-golfing-pilgrim-5557921-details.aspx|website=christies.com|publisher=Longmans|accessdate=20 April 2015}} * ''The Book of Golf and Golfers'' (1899){{cite book|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Horace G.|title=The Book of Golf and Golfers|date=1899|publisher=Longmans Green and Co.|location=London; New York; Bombay|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OqwTAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Horace+Hutchinson+golf&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDsQuwUwBWoVChMI_Zvzw827yAIVRemACh2XuQnV#v=onepage&q=Horace%20Hutchinson%20golf&f=false|accessdate=12 October 2015}} * ''A Friend of Nelson'' (1902) * ''Bert Edward, The Golf Caddie'' (1903) * ''The New Book of Golf'' (1912) – with contributions by [[May Hezlet]], et al.{{cite book|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Horace G.|title=The New Book of Golf|date=1912|publisher=Longmans, Green & Co.|location=London, England|url=http://chestofbooks.com/sports/golf/New-Book-On-Golf/#.VTKLCJUtHIU|accessdate=18 April 2015}} * ''Life of [[Sir John Lubbock]], Lord Avebury'' (1914){{cite book|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Horace G.|title=Life of Sir John Lubbock, Lord Avebury|date=28 May 1914|publisher=Macmillan (London)|url=https://archive.org/details/lifeofsirjohnlub01hutcuoft|accessdate=18 April 2015}} * ''The Eight of Diamonds: the Story of Week-End'' (1914) * ''Fifty Years of Golf'' (1919){{cite web |title=50 Years of Golf, by Horace G. Hutchinson |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/37394/37394-h/37394-h.htm |publisher=Country Life |accessdate=18 April 2015}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hutchinson, Horace}} [[Category:English male golfers]] [[Category:British writers]] [[Category:Male suicides]] [[Category:Suicides in London]] [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1932 deaths]]
